QuoteText: When the fossils are aged by the rocks -That's one thing. But really! -- the rocks date the fossils much more accurately. [Or was it the other way around] lol. Cuvier collaborated for several years with Alexandre Brongniart, an instructor at the Paris mining school, to produce a monograph on the geology of the region around Paris. They published a preliminary version in 1808 and the final version was published in 1811. In this monograph they identified characteristic fossils of different rock layers that they used to analyze the geological column, the ordered layers of sedimentary rock, of the Paris basin. They concluded that the layers had been laid down over an extended period during which there clearly had been faunal succession and that the area had been submerged under sea water at times and at other times under fresh water. Along with William Smith's work during the same period on a geological map of England, which also used characteristic fossils and the principle of faunal succession to correlate layers of sedimentary rock, the monograph helped establish the scientific discipline of stratigraphy. It was a major development in the history of paleontology and the history of geology.
ResponseText: I don't know. Perhaps if you could only ask the creationist scientists who devised the methods of relative dating, Georges Cuvier and contemporaries for example. They recognized that the fossils from each stratigraphic layer were different from other layers. They also recognized that some widely spread fossils appeared in the strata in the same order wherever they were found. They hypothesized that the lower fossils were older than those in more shallow deposits. They assigned names to the strata, and after that they used the fossils to identify the various layers wherever they were found. They named the typical fossil layers to represent the relative ages. After than, when they found a fossil they could assign it to the appropriate age. As Wikipedia says: The principle is still good in that certain types of fossils only appear in rocks of a certain age. For example, trilobites only appear in rocks of the early Devonian and older. If you find a trilobite fossil, you know for sure that it did not come from Permian rocks. Other fossils were also found in rocks of a limited age. When several of these fossil types are considered together, they are typically grouped differently in rocks of various ages. These groupings are called suites. Therefore, by identifying a particular suite of fossils I can assign an approximate age to the stratum in which that group of fossils was found. Of course, these same creationists realized that the multiple strata could not represent one great flood. As a result, they realized that what they read in the Bible could not possibly be literally true. They hypothesized a series of creations and destructions - multiple creations and destructions by multiple floods. So modern paleontology has creationists to thank for the method of relative dating that is still used today to give approximate dates for fossils. It is quite reliable. But modern creationists have reverted to the dark ages before the development of scientific thought. Maintaining the fantasy that the mythology of the Bible is real is so important that creationists reject scientific theories developed by early creationist scientists. Instead creationists now point to people like Mr. Kent Hovind and Ken Ham as "creation scientists."
